description: tall blueish/greyish green with upright branches
light-green to grey-green, growing in tribes.  This may not be a fully accepted species.  The only descriptive source I could find was in german
fruit: spherical fruit, small, ripening slowly from lightgreen to darker
ribs: 30 or more, growing in a spiral
spines: white areoles, with 3-5 yellow mid-spines 1-1.5cm long, with 20-60 yellow-white edge-spines (like fur)

description: tree-like: tall trunk with crown of branching stems
spines: dense, straight, brown spines of 6-15cm (fewer in older growth)

aka: Parodia parvula, Parodia winbergii, Parodia tillii, Parodia pusilla, Parodia parvula, Parodia pachysa, Parodia purpureo-aurea, Parodia chirimoyarana, Parodia chaetocarpa, Parodia cardenasii, Parodia carapariana, Parodia bellavistana, Parodia setispina
flowers: sulphur yellow to orange, pericarpels with white wool in spring/summer
origin: Argentina, Bolivia,  900 to 1600 (-2200?) metres above sea leve
spines: central: 6-12, fine flexible, needle-like, straight, reddish brown, 3-12 mm long.  Radial: 20-30, lighter coloured, white or brown-tipped, 3-8 mm long
